Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Commercialization of a City Scale Weather Radar
Award.AbstractNarration:
The public's appetite for detailed weather information is on the rise, but current weather forecasting accuracy is not satisfactory, especially when it comes to predictions for small-scale areas (e.g., neighborhood-, or block-level). Current national radar systems provide weather information updated once every 5 minutes and the quality of the data degrades considerably with increased distance from the radar. Therefore, in case of severe weather, some events might remain unnoticed or the information about them might not be delivered on time. A next generation, short-range weather radar developed at UMass Amherst promises higher temporal and spatial resolution as well as a reliable, low-cost operation.

The new class of compact weather radar developed by this team promises much higher data resolution and can be deployed on rooftops, communications towers, and other infrastructure elements, without expensive structure modifications. The low-weight of the system allows for a 2 person installation without the usage of a crane or helicopter further reducing the overall cost. The radar radiates a peak power on the order of 100W, rather than in the range of 250-500kW - a standard for current operational weather radars. Therefore the proposed sensing system does not pose any radiation hazard. Due to its short-range nature of operation, observation of the weather close to the ground, which directly affects local communities, is possible. With the proposed technology, up-to-the-second radar information will be transmitted to individuals and organizations that make critical decisions about the weather.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF I-Corps program consists of two parts, a series of courses and lectures and an intense customer discovery. All three members (Entrepreneurial Lead (EL), Mentor, and PI) of “Commercialization of a City Scale Weather Radar” participated in these events. The EL gave a short talk describing the technology and the potential market during the kick-off meeting in Atlanta, GA. During the cohorts weekly webinars the EL presented the latest outcomes of the team’s customer discovery activities. Finally, a summary of the activities performed within the scope of the I-Corps program was presented during the closing workshop.

The core of the I-Corps program was an intense customer discovery. The team conducted 95 interviews (mostly performed by the EL), including 80 personal interviews in 3 countries (Poland, Belgium and USA). Interviews in the Unites States required travel to the following states: Texas, Georgia, New York, Connecticut and Massachusetts. The EL also travelled to Brussels, Belgium to interview multiple companies in the weather industry during the World Meteorological Expo.

The technology under investigation was focused on a novel phased-array weather radar developed at the University of Massachusetts. The team conducted a series of interviews with organizations and groups that are in the weather forecast and detection business or are substantially impacted by weather. Interviews were performed with entities from the following sectors:

-        Government institutions (National Weather Service (NWS), Department of Transportation (DOT), Emergency Management Agency)

-        Aviation sector (major airlines, major and local airports, pilots)

-        Outdoor event organizers (MLB, PGA Tour, Formula 1)

-        Data resellers (Weather Analytics, Ubimet, Verisk Climate, WSI)

-        TV stations (Weather Channel, CNN, ABC, NBC, etc)

-        Off-shore sector (Philips Conoco)

-        Environmental measurement sector (Vaisala, Schneider Electric, EWR)

We started our interview with institutions from the government sector, since the are natural adopters of our weather technology. The NWS operates currently over 150 weather radars in the USA but is concerned about coverage caps in some parts of the country. In addition, DOTs on the US East Coast are actively looking for a solution, which can save money and increase public safety especially during winter weather events. We have received positive feedback that our technology has the potential to solve some of the issues these institutions deal with. However, during our interviews it turned out that government institutions are not a natural partner for a startup company.

Our interviews with institutions from the aviation sector unveiled that data our technology would provide is already provided through other solutions. For example, commercial airplanes are equipped with weather radars, pilots have access to real-time weather information from ground-based networks and satellite networks via the Internet, which was not the case even five years ago. Private pilots would like more precise weather information, but they choose not to fly even if a small risk of inclement weather is present.

Outdoor event organizers were interested in our technology and could see the potential advantages of using it for emergency management, but currently the cost of our solution does not justify the benefit.
